commands.description: Creates a new Git repository. If 'directory' is not provided, it initializes the current directory.
commands.why: This is the foundational step to start versioning a project locally with Git, creating the necessary '.git' directory.
commands.when: When starting a new project from scratch, or when you want to convert an unversioned project into a Git repository.

commands.description: Clones a repository from a given URL into a new directory. If 'directory' is omitted, it creates one with the same name as the repository.
commands.why: To get a local working copy of an existing remote repository, enabling you to contribute or simply examine its contents.
commands.when: When you want to contribute to a remote project (e.g., from GitHub) or fetch a project to your local machine.

commands.description: Sets a Git configuration value. `--global` applies to all your repositories, otherwise it's per-repository.
commands.why: To customize your Git environment, such as setting your user name and email, which are included in your commits.
commands.when: Typically configured once after Git installation (global) or when setting up a new repository (local).

commands.description: Shows the working tree status, including changes staged, unstaged, and untracked files.
commands.why: To quickly see the current state of your repository and what changes are pending.
commands.when: Frequently, to check what you've modified, what's ready to be committed, or if there are new files to track.

commands.description: Shows commit logs, displaying a history of all commits in the repository.
commands.why: To review the project's history, understand changes over time, and identify specific commits.
commands.when: When you need to find out who made a change, when it was made, or what changes were introduced in a commit.

commands.description: Shows changes between commits, commit and working tree, etc. `git diff` shows unstaged changes, `git diff --staged` shows staged changes.
commands.why: To review exactly what modifications have been made to files before staging or committing them.
commands.when: Before `git add` to review unstaged changes, or before `git commit` to review staged changes.

commands.description: Adds file contents to the index (staging area). `git add .` stages all changes.
commands.why: To select which changes from your working directory you want to include in your next commit.
commands.when: After modifying files and before committing, to prepare the snapshot of changes.

commands.description: Removes files from the working tree and from the index.
commands.why: To stop tracking a file and remove it from the repository history for future commits.
commands.when: When you want to delete a file that is currently tracked by Git.

commands.description: Records changes to the repository, creating a new commit with the staged changes and a descriptive message.
commands.why: To save a snapshot of your project at a specific point in time to the local repository history.
commands.when: After you have staged all the changes you want to include for a logical unit of work.

commands.description: Combines staged changes with the previous commit, or allows you to edit the previous commit message.
commands.why: To fix a mistake in the last commit, add forgotten files, or refine the commit message without creating a new commit.
commands.when: Immediately after making a commit if you realize you forgot something or made a typo in the message, and before pushing to a shared remote.
commands.example: git commit --amend -m "Fix typo in authentication commit message"

commands.description: Restores specified paths in the working tree to a state from the index or a commit. Use `--staged` to unstage a file.
commands.why: To discard unstaged changes in a file or to unstage changes that were accidentally added.
commands.when: When you want to revert a file to its last committed state (unstaged) or remove it from the staging area.

commands.description: Resets the current HEAD to the specified state. `--soft` keeps changes staged, `--mixed` unstages, `--hard` discards.
commands.why: To undo commits, rearrange history, or unstage changes.
commands.when: When you need to revert multiple commits, clean up your local history, or unstage all current changes.

commands.description: Creates a new commit that undoes the changes made in a previous commit.
commands.why: To undo changes from a specific commit while preserving the project history, which is safe for shared repositories.
commands.when: When you need to undo changes from a pushed commit without rewriting shared history.

commands.description: Lists, creates, or deletes branches. Without arguments, lists local branches.
commands.why: To create isolated lines of development, allowing work on different features or bug fixes concurrently.
commands.when: When starting a new feature, fixing a bug, or experimenting with new ideas without affecting the main codebase.

commands.description: Switches branches or restores working tree files. `checkout -b` creates and switches to a new branch.
commands.why: To move between different lines of development or to create a new branch from your current position.
commands.when: When you want to work on a different feature, switch to a bugfix branch, or return to a previous commit.

commands.description: (Newer alternative to checkout) Switches branches. `switch -c` creates and switches to a new branch.
commands.why: Provides a clearer separation of concerns between switching branches and restoring files compared to `git checkout`.
commands.when: Prefer `git switch` for changing branches and `git restore` for reverting file changes.

commands.description: Joins two or more development histories together.
commands.why: To integrate changes from one branch into another, combining different lines of work.
commands.when: After completing work on a feature branch, to integrate it into a `develop` or `main` branch.

commands.description: Reapplies commits on top of another base tip, often used to integrate changes from an upstream branch without merge commits.
commands.why: To create a cleaner, linear project history by moving a feature branch's commits to the tip of another branch.
commands.when: Before merging a feature branch into `main` or `develop`, to ensure a clean history without unnecessary merge commits.

commands.description: Manages the set of tracked repositories (remotes). `-v` shows URLs, `add` adds a new remote.
commands.why: To configure connections to remote versions of your repository, typically hosted on platforms like GitHub.
commands.when: To see which remotes are configured, or to add a new remote repository to your local clone.

commands.description: Downloads objects and refs from another repository.
commands.why: To retrieve new commits and branches from a remote repository without integrating them into your local working branch.
commands.when: To see what changes have occurred on the remote before deciding to pull or merge.

commands.description: Fetches from and integrates with another repository or a local branch.
commands.why: To update your current local working branch with the latest changes from a remote branch.
commands.when: Regularly, to synchronize your local repository with the remote, especially before starting new work.

commands.description: Updates remote refs along with associated objects.
commands.why: To upload your local commits to a remote repository, making them available to others.
commands.when: After committing changes locally and wanting to share them with the team or update the central repository.
